title: At close of business on 27 January 2021, will the upper limit of the Federal Reserve's target range for the federal funds rate be lower, the same, or higher than it was at close of business on 16 December 2020?
preds: Higher is out of the question given the poor state of the economy, lower seems unlikely as they'd be pushing negative rates which isn't going to happen anytime soon.  Leaves me with Same.

As posted here. 
https://www.bankrate.com/rates/interest-rates/federal-funds-rate.aspx
This week, 0.25 ; a month ago , 0.25 ; a year ago, 1.75
Target rate == (0.00 , 0.25)
Not going to change for a while still.
Inferred from Fed funds futures for March 15th using the methodology of the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta.

- Two COVID vaccines have provided more than 90% effectiveness, but distribution and immunity are still projected to be months if not a year away for the US. 
- US is implementing harder restrictions across the country as cases climb.  https://www.politico.com/news/2020/11/16/moderna-coronavirus-vaccine-effective-436776
-https://www.foxnews.com/politics/governors-bring-back-severe-coronavirus-lockdowns-tighten-restrictions-as-cases-hit-record-highs
-
Most recent Reserve Board meeting remains concerned over impact of COVID on economy. Expect to hold rates steady for the long term.

The current target rate range is 0.00-0.25. The rate has never been set below that level. The FOMC has stated they intend to maintain this range through 2023. https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomcprojtabl20200916.htm The upper limit will not go lower. FED Chair Powell is on record stating he would not support negative interest rates, even during a crisis and there has been no reporting or statements from the FOMC that would indicate a sea change in view among its members.
https://www.cnbc.com/2019/09/18/powell-doesnt-see-the-fed-ever-using-negative-interest-rates-even-in-times-of-crisis.html The FED is also unlikely to raise the upper limit with unemployment projected to be still near 7%. https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/forecast
Central bank normally does not make large moves in the transition period between presidents. If one believes the projections for a D victory on 03 Nov, this pattern will hold for the period cited.

- EU locking down again
- No supplemental bill
- NJ threatens lockdown

- Positive economic indicators last week resulted and anticipation of a blue wave leading to increased federal spending caused the yield curve to steepen.  However, due to the 27 Jan 21 timeline, this will not impact our results.

CPI for September fell to .2 from .4, well below Fed target of 2%.  
- After the 2008 recession, it took the Fed 7 years to raise rates by 25 basis points. 
- Fed officials are urging Congress for more stimulus.

With FAIT (flexible avg inflation targeting), even higher than target inflation will not move the Fed to hike, at least as early as Jan 2021. Dot plots are flat until 2023! There is some discussion of negative rates, while unlikely, it is a possibility.

https://www.ft.com/content/afe7bdfd-84b4-4405-965e-234a1e9b39df
While the language from the FOMC`s minutes is frustratingly vague. They do go on to say that the zero percent rate isnt cast in stone can be changed if there is a faster than expected recovery, or spike in inflation( unlikely in the  near term). or emergence of Asset bubbles (they dont say what constitutes one) Raising my increase estimate higher

- The president ended another round of stimulus checks
- Unemployment still hovers around 8%
- Fed President Powell urged Congress for more stimulus money on Tuesday. 
- All three combine to make economic improvement less likely.  Without substantial growth rates will not change until late 2021 IAW the FED.

At this point with the fed signalling it's intent to keep rates close to zero don't see any change in status quo unless inflation picks up. Powell has mentioned his stance on negative interest rates in may..don't see any reason why he would change his view so suddenly.

lowering would mean USA is trending towards negative rates, this seems like an extremely improbable event over the next 6 months. economic growth would need to swiftly return and inflation would have to rise for the fed to lift the upper bound. this does not look probable this winter given potential for another spike in covid, continued small business closures and travel/hospitality struggles.

Beginning of March the FOMC set the upper bound to 1/4 %. In all subsequent meetings the FOMC stated that it will keep the target range at similar levels until the economy recovers. Since Corona will get worse in the coming weeks and months there is no reason why the rate should be higher. A lower rate is theoretically possible (see EU) but it is questionable whether the FOMC goes this route. See https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomccalendars.htm

- WoW Jobless Claims Rose : 870,000
-3 month T-bill holds at .10
-6 month T-bill holds at .11 for 5 weeks in a row

I believe they will keep the rates the same, but believe they could raise it by 0.25 and follow the pattern during the recovery of the Great Recession. 3rd Quarter economic numbers and 4th Quarter economic number will likely show recovery. 9/16 
Reuters - The Federal Reserve on Wednesday vowed to keep interest rates near zero until inflation is on track to overshoot the U.S. central bank’s 2% target, a bold new promise aimed at bringing millions of out-of-work Americans back to the labor market. But the new guidance also marked the start of a vigorous monetary policy debate as the Fed shifts from a crisis-era focus on keeping markets afloat during the coronavirus pandemic to managing what it now sees as a steady, multi-year recovery. All but one Fed policymaker saw rates staying at their near-zero level through 2022. Just four saw them higher than that in 2023. “Effectively what we are saying is that rates will remain highly accommodative until the economy is far along in its recovery,” Fed Chair Jerome Powell said in a news conference following the release of the policy statement and new economic projections.

parsing the question upper limit of the target range (16.Dec.2020) (%/%/%) (read P(lower/same/higher)) (27.Jan.2021)?
Always purposefully ambiguous in its wording, the FED communicates with the given number of its upper limit of the target range the following: The intended upper limit of the weighted average (a) of the interest rates that depository institutions (b) pay to each other (c) to borrow reserve balances held at the Federal Reserve to maintain depository institutions' reserve requirements (d), for the next 7 week period. (1) If either/or (a), (b), (c) and (d) would be modified (change of law or application of the law (*)) the same mechanism might then apply to a different set of facts. Yet this might still be the (%/%/%) number. This is at least a non-0 % chance, so (+1/+1/+1) at least.
If nothing where changed, the question would then be about what factors one considers to be relevant to yielding the same upper limit of the target range, almost year over year. baserate Between December 2008 and December 2015 the target rate remained at 0.00–0.25%, as reaction to the 2007/2008 financial crisis. (1)  factors This suffices for me for now in establishing the equation: (sum of factors leading to perception of financial crisis) -> unchanged low target rate.
Yet, many factors may come into play and I see no way to accurately assess all probabilities - for now, so (+3/+3/+3). Examples: 
Long-term processes:
- After the gold standard and the 1976 switch to fiat money, a change in humankinds monetary policy is imminent, given the trusted middle man bank is no longer necessary with blockchain. Just as trust would have to evolve from balance-sheet-numbers backed by 'gold in someone's vault' to be backed by 'numbers on somebody's paper', they now will evolve to be backed by 'numbers on somebodys servers'. Yet I doubt this will happen within the single year in question here.
- US-China trade war.
- Climate Change; Storm Season devastating continental US, thus devastating housing market - or giving rise to orchestrated re-building of US-Cities - this time with a third space.
Short-term processes:
- US presidential election.
- San-Andreas-Quake. conclusio So if nothing of that sort happened - and I am basing my current estimate on that hypothesis, I deem 'same' most likely by far, as financial crisis 2007/2008 is precedent and I actively expect not many new solutions to come about, with the current US focus on BLM and Trump. (1) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_funds_rate
(2) e.g. by creating a new agency/name/institution/bundle/vector to replace the 'other banks' requirements, thus effectively freeing bank's collective responsibility towards the FED and creating a new playing field and thus (shortlived?) new room for growth on paper the public might not understand right away. Or that happend or would be used by Trumps destabilization-tour, am not competent here, just speculating ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Sep 16 FOMC Meeting - Committee decided to keep the target range for the federal funds rate at 0 to 1/4 percent and expects it will be appropriate to maintain this target range until labor market conditions have reached levels consistent with the Committee's assessments of maximum employment and inflation has risen to 2 percent and is on track to moderately exceed 2 percent for some time.
- Lower would mean a negative rate which the US has never done although Europe has attempted this 
- The FOMC Economic Projections (SEP) which includes federal funds rate forecasts at 0-.25 now extend out through 2023.
- Economic recovery would have to be substantial to move rates. 
- Another stimulus bill has not gained support and winter may increase COVID caseses according to projections.

The President has pressured the Federal Reserve to lower interest rates since 2016. With the Pandemic, unemployment rates, and the upcoming election, there is pressure to keep the economy moving. I can't see the interest rates changing until after there is a vaccine,.
Use of CME FedWatch, speech from JPowell.

I believe that many people are judging our economy by the stock market, which in my view is grossly overvalued. The markets seem to ignore the economic time bombs that will explode once economic stimulus, beefed-up unemployment benefits and eviction moratoriums end, and it certainly looks like the Covid-19 infection rates are going up again. So there are significant economic risks, and in my view a substantial chance of a stock-market crash that might lead the Fed to move rates lower.

Higher:
The Fed has never previously risen the federal funds target rate during a recession (or the upper limit post 2008). The two most likely scenarios I can think of that could cause the fed to increase the upper limit would be an unprecedentedly rapid increase in inflation (otherwise Such an increase would not be in any way accordance to their dual mandate), or some sort of mistake in the implementation and communication of the Feds intended policy. However, these strike me as sufficiently unlikely as to be justified in rounding down their probability to 0%, rather than rounding them up to 1%. Even though this question is asking about December to January change, I would even go so far as to apply this rounded 0% estimate to the scenario that the Fed would increase it's rate from any point between my answering this question the first time (Sep 19 2020) and December 27th. This latter more general estimate is important for my other calculations. Same vs lower:
The primary consideration for my 96% estimate is the base rate of decreasing either the upper limit (or for historical data decreasing the target rate) below 0-0.25%. A change in to negative interest rates would be unprecedented, and there is little reason for the fed to decrease its upper limit while keeping its lower limit the same. However, there are many factors that make it much more likely that the Fed would decrease the target range (and thus the upper limit). We are currently in a recession, the natural rate of interest is lower than in previous decades meaning unconventional policy is more necessary to provide policy space, and other countries have began to explore negative interest rates as legitimate tools of monetary policy albeit with varying degrees of success. Nonetheless, recent federal reserve minutes and release statements make it clear that all FOMC voting members are not big fans of enacting negative interest rates in the US, with perhaps the possible but unlikely exception of Kaplan based on the vague wording in the September press release statement. So I put the odds of the Fed decreasing the higher upper limit FFR between the stated dates at about 4%. I would have said 5% if the date range was between now and the January date, since I think earlier decreases would in my mind make a December to January decrease slightly less likely.

I think there is a very small chance of a move up, and a virtually no chance of a move down, as I believe the Federal Reserve is already at its lower limit on rates and will pursue other mechanisms to flood the economy with money if the economy weakens.
How low can you go? (Limbo bar).  Muricans not ready for real negative rates as per some places on planet. Per recent remarks by Fed, long term outlook continuing low for foreseeable future.
The thing is absent a glorious 2 quarter run of over 3.5% growth, rates are never going up ever.  Remember the song The Vapors - Turning Japanese ! https://youtu.be/IWWwM2wwMww

More than likely through all of 2021 as well. "A survey of Fed officials showed the group expects rates to remain at or near zero through 2023." https://www.cnn.com/2020/09/16/economy/federal-reserve-september-meeting/index.html
